After completing this course, you will never see the world the same way again. This course provides an overview of how the eyes and brain work together to enable visual perception. The overview includes an introduction to the structure and function of the human eye and visual brain. You will also learn about the professional pathways open to vision scientists and optometrists and how discoveries in optometry and vision science are used to improve vision and combat disease. The course also builds the graduate attributes required by vision scientists and optometrists by providing an introduction to research and communication skills including critical thinking, statistics, collaborative research and group presentation. It is the first course in the vision science major in the science or advanced science programs and in the optometry program.


Assumed Knowledge: HSC Mathematics is assumed knowledge. HSC Physics is recommended knowledge. Bridging Courses are available to students entering UNSW; these courses usually run in January - February, before the start of Semester 1. Students who do not have the appropriate assumed or recommended knowledge are strongly advised to undertake the relevant Bridging Course/s, or other appropriate preparation.

There are three parts to this assessment. The first part will involve a written assignment to consolidate and reinforce how participation of a consulation at the UNSW Optometry Clinic or a Vision Science research project contributed to personal growth in understanding of the discipline of optometry and vision science, and the professional context in which it is practiced.

The second part will be a group presentation which will review the student's abliity to formulate a question relating to ocular and visual pathway structure in perception, and demonstrate literature search method and analysis of quality of evidence in relation to the formulated question through a group work presentation and participation.

The third part involves completing Moodle modules on self management skills for effective learning.

Feedback: marks for written assignment and group presentation within 2 weeks of assessment

The overview includes an introduction to the structure and function of the human eye and visual brain. You will also learn about the professional pathways open to vision scientists and optometrists and how discoveries in optometry and vision science are used to improve vision and combat disease. The course also builds the graduate attributes required by vision scientists and optometrists by providing an introduction to research and communication skills including critical thinking, statistics, collaborative research and group presentation. It is the first course in the vision science major in the science or advanced science programs and in the optometry program.

Assumed Knowledge: HSC Mathematics is assumed knowledge. HSC Physics is recommended knowledge. Bridging Courses are available to students entering UNSW; these courses usually run in January - February, before the start of Semester 1. Students who do not have the appropriate assumed or recommended knowledge are strongly advised to undertake the relevant Bridging Course/s, or other appropriate preparation.

Objectives: This course provides an understanding of geometric and physical optics. It is the first optics course in the Vision Science/Clinical Optometry program. This course will be delivered by lectures, laboratory classes and tutorial exercises designed to present, with least complexity, concepts in optics relevant to optometry & vision science.


Brief curriculum:


Geometrical optics: Basics of light and light propagation, rectilinear propagation of light, refraction and reflection at the plane and spherical surfaces, prisms, thin lenses, thick lenses, optical systems with multiple surfaces, simple magnifiers, compound magnifiers, telescopes, microscopes, stops, pupils and windows.


Physical optics: The wave nature of light, superposition of waves, interference, diffraction, and polarisation. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5481205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial group work","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Students will be asked to work in groups and solve a given problem relating to topics covered in the lectures and tutorials, with two groups randomly selected every alternate week.  The students will be assessed on their ability to illustrate strategies for solving optical problems using appropriate formulae as well as their ability to think critically and proactively in their approach to the problem.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5081205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online and Class Tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are given the opportunity to revise their acquired knowledge through a series of tests - both online and in-class - that are given during crucial periods in the semester. Two Moodle-based multiple choice tests are given to students to complete at the start of Week 5 and Week 12, where students answer 10 questions to prepare for the 1st class test and the final examination. Two 60-minute formal class tests are given in Week 6 and Week 10, where students are expected to demonstrate their knowledge of topics, tutorial problems and labs covered in the preceding weeks in greater detail. 

Students gain immediate feedback on their Moodle quizzes. Generalised class test feedback and answers are provided on Moodle a fortnight after each test and students are also given the opportunity for more personalised feedback on request.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5881205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"55","description":"

A final examination will be held to test the knowledge and skills gained by the student through lectures, tutorials and lab experiments conducted through the session. Students are assessed on their ability to write definitions, derive formulae, draw ray diagrams, and solve problems through multiple choice and short answer questions. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5c81205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5881205cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619c0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Prior to each lab, students work in groups to submit lab reports to Moodle detailing experiments undertaken during the previous lab. In each lab report form, students record measurements and make calculations based on the experiments performed during the lab. The form also includes a set of questions at the end that probe student’s understanding of the lab, their observation skills and the results obtained. Written feedback is provided to each group every fortnight.

of Medicine and Health","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"VISN1221 - Visual Optics","description":"

This course builds on knowledge and skills gained in the geometric and physical optics (VISN 1111 course) to the optical characteristics of the human eye in relation to visual performance including errors of refraction and measurement and corrections using fundamental principles of light and optics.


Brief Curriculum


Visual Optics: Ametropia and its correction, accommodation, retinal image analysis, astigmatism, measurement of visual performance, the optics of subjective refraction, near correction, optical factors affecting visual resolution, ocular refractive error corrections, aberrations, dispersion,  entoptic phenomena, introduction to spectacle lenses and their subsidiary effects, design considerations of spectacle lenses.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7181e05cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396190c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-semester exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Knowledge and understanding of the topics covered till Week 5 will be tested. Ability to write definitions, derive formulae, draw ray diagrams, and solve problems such as those worked out in class will be tested. Feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of the assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3181e05cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3981e05cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3981e05cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0281e05cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group work","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Group work (Lab): In each lab, students will record measurements and make calculations. The lab will involve questions to probe student’s understanding of the lab including ability to illustrate strategies for solving optical problems using appropriate formulae, their observation skills and the results obtained. Informal feedback will be provided during the subsequent week.

Group work (Tutorials):  Students will work in groups and solve a given problem based on topics covered in the lectures and tutorials at the end of tutorial session combined with two journal articles appraisal presentations.

Knowledge and understanding of the topics covered in the lectures and tutorials. Ability to illustrate strategies for solving optical problems using appropriate formulae.

contentlets.description:
This course builds on knowledge and skills gained in the geometric and physical optics (VISN 1111 course) to the optical characteristics of the human eye in relation to visual performance including errors of refraction and measurement and corrections using fundamental principles of light and optics.

Brief Curriculum

Visual Optics: Ametropia and its correction, accommodation, retinal image analysis, astigmatism, measurement of visual performance, the optics of subjective refraction, near correction, optical factors affecting visual resolution, ocular refractive error corrections, aberrations, dispersion,  entoptic phenomena, introduction to spectacle lenses and their subsidiary effects, design considerations of spectacle lenses.
contentlets.title: Visual Optics

Objectives: An understanding of the anatomy and physiology of the eye, ocular adnexa and surrounds and an introduction to the visual pathways. This course aims to relate form and function of the ocular system.


Brief Curriculum: Introduction to the gross anatomy of the eye and adnexa (including nerve and blood supply); introduction to cellular anatomy of the components of the eye and ocular adnexa. This includes an introduction to the optic nerve and visual pathways. Physiology of the eye including the ocular surface dynamics, corneal wound healing, aqueous humour dynamics and intraocular pressure regulation, neural control of the pupil and physiology and biochemistry of the retina and retinal pigment epithelium.

Objectives: An understanding of processing in the visual system. Brief curriculum: Spatial vision: visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, aliasing, alignment thresholds; Colour vision: retinal and cortical processing, colour constancy, colour identification; Binocularity: models of depth perception, correspondence, Panum's area, horopter, stereoacuity, monocular depth perception, summation, stereopsis tests; Motion perception: models of motion perception, adaptation, directional selectivity, first and second order motion; Cognition: shape recognition, face perception, visual illusions, visual hallucinations, visual attention, visual search and pop-out.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5591285cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

All course content will be assessed in the final exam. The format will be short answer questions and multiple choice questions, which will assess your understanding and your ability to clearly explain topics presented in the course.   

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1991285cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment item requires students to write a research essay on an assigned topic. Topics questions are released at the beginning of semester and focusses on key aspects of the course. Students may devise their own questions, but this must be approved by the course coordinator by week 4. The essay will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. A written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.  

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9591285cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment item assesses the ability to directly participate in all aspects of the research process. Students will be required to independently conduct two experiments, analyse data by applying both descriptive and inferential statistics, and communicate findings in written form as a laboratory report. A written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.

Objectives: An understanding of the basic mechanisms of disease as they relate to the eye. 


Brief curriculum: Microbiology: microbial identification, bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasitic infection, prions, epidemiology of infection, infection control, common ocular infections; Immunology: cells of the immune system, normal and abnormal function; Disease processes: cell injury, adaptation, hypoxia, ischemia, inflammation, cell growth, vascular disease, atherosclerosis, neoplasia, aging, genetic abnormalities, diabetes, hypertension, intracranial disease.

Objectives: An understanding of the development and aging of the visual system. The effect of disease on the visual system is briefly discussed. Brief curriculum: Development of the visual system: embryology of the eye and brain, axon pathfinding, receptive field development, development of the visual cortex, critical periods, plasticity, reorganisation of cortical inputs; Development of vision: spatial vision, colour vision, motion perception, shape perception, binocularity; Ageing: physiology of aging, effect of age on brain function, effect of age on the visual system, effect of age on vision; Effect of disease: the effects of brain injury, retinal disease, refractive error, amblyopia and drugs on visual perception are briefly covered.

Objectives: An understanding of the new developments occurring in vision science.


Brief curriculum: A review of interesting topics in modern visual science. Topics to be discussed may include: animal vision, machine vision, retinal implants for people with visual impairment, blind sight, stem cell implantation, cures for myopia, cures for presbyopia.


A portion of this course deals with public health issues in vision: the importance of epidemiological and clinical trial research, vision loss in the developing world, preventable vision loss, eye care in Australia's indigenous communities.

contentlets.description:
Objectives: An understanding of the new developments occurring in vision science.

Brief curriculum: A review of interesting topics in modern visual science. Topics to be discussed may include: animal vision, machine vision, retinal implants for people with visual impairment, blind sight, stem cell implantation, cures for myopia, cures for presbyopia.

A portion of this course deals with public health issues in vision: the importance of epidemiological and clinical trial research, vision loss in the developing world, preventable vision loss, eye care in Australia's indigenous communities.
contentlets.title: New Developments in Vision Science

Students in this course will undertake research under the supervision of an academic in the School of Optometry and Vision Science. Advanced training will be given in selected areas of vision science, including a supervised program that places emphasis on the use of specialised techniques relevant to the research area. A written research report and research proposal is required. In addition, this course includes a formal component of seminars and tutorials/workshops, which provide in-depth research experience and skills that will aid students in undertaking their research. At the end of the thesis, students will be required to present their work in a school seminar. 


This course is only available to students undertaking vision science Honours in the School of Optometry and Vision Science in the Faculty of Science


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c5a1ac5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

The written research report is the major assessment component of the honours year that reports the student's independent research. The report should be no longer than 10,000 words, and should be prepared as a journal submission in this field of research. This generally involves an abstract, introduction, methods, results and discussion. Though variations of this format is allowed given disciplinary variations regarding how research is to be reported.

Written research report is to be submitted at the end of the second semester of enrolment. This report will be marked by two independent assessors in the school or elsewhere when expertise is needed. This assessment is based on:

  • Depth and breath of discussion
  • Content of report, coverage of key issues
  • Appropriate use of figures and tables
  • Correctness and appropriate use of reference
  • Organisation, clarity and format in appropriate scientific style.

Honours Coordinator returns the report with marks and assessor's comments

Fortnightly workshops (2-3hrs) which covers topics such as ethics, research design, statistics and data analysis, thesis writing and synthesis, presentation skills and professional development. Fornightly exercises (e.g., quizzes, problem based learning examples and case studies) will be given and students will be required to submit them for assessment as a portfolio. 

 


Honours Coordinator returns portfolio with marks and assessor's comments

The literature review provides a concise (no more than 5000 words) and detailed account of published work that is most relevant to the chosen research topic. This literature review should provide an indication of the problem(s) being addressed and how previous research have approached its investigation. Students are required to provide critical analysis and synthesis of the research with the view of presenting and proposing their own research question. 

The literature review and research proposal will be marked by the supervisor based on:

  • Demonstrated knowledge of topic area
  • Content and organisation, coverage of key issues
  • Depth and breath of analysis and discussion 

Honours Coordinator returns reports with marks and comments

Students in this course will undertake research under the supervision of an academic in the School of Optometry and Vision Science. Advanced training will be given in selected areas of vision science, including a supervised program that emphasises the use of specialised techniques relevant to the research area (for example laboratory-based, clinical or public heath techniques/applications), A written literature review and research proposal, ethics application and final research thesis are required. In addition, this course includes regular attendance at seminars. During the Honours year, students will be required to present two research seminars in the School of Optometry and Vision Science.


This course is only available to students undertaking Vision Science Honours within the School of Optometry and Vision Science, Faculty of Science. The course runs for the a whole year and requires enrolment each term, for 3 terms (16UOC each term). Applications are only accepted to commence in T1 or T3. All enrolment in VISN4016 should be with School's consent to ensure that students are only able to enrol if they have an appropriate project and supervisor.

The final written research report is a major assessment component of the honours year that reports the outcomes of the student's independent research. The report should be no longer than 20,000 words, and prepared in a thesis style. This generally involves an abstract, introduction, methods, results and crical discussion, with limitations and future directions for the work. Variations of this format may be be allowed with consultation and approval form the Honours convenor with consulataion given disciplinary variations regarding how research is to be reported.

The Honours thesis is submitted at the end of the second semester of enrolment.

The thesis will be marked by two independent assessors for the SOVS or externally for sufficient expertise in the filed of research as needed. A thesis marking rubric will be proved, bassed on This assessment is based on:

  • Depth and breath of discussion
  • Content of report, coverage of key issues
  • Appropriate use of figures and tables
  • Correctness and appropriate use of reference
  • Organisation, clarity and format in appropriate scientific style.

Honours convenor will return the report with marks and assessor's comments to the student and supervisor.

Final seminar in the School of Optometry and Vision Science with academics and postgraduate students.

The seminar includes introduction, methods, results and comprehensive and critical discussion of research findings in relation to current knowledge in the area. This will be followed by questions from seminar attendees. Marks based on scores from academics at the seminar. Summary of marks and comments will be provided as feedback by the Honours convenor following the seminar.

Seminar in the School of Optometry and Vision Science with academics and postgraduate students.This isheld at the end of Semester 1 (or in mid-Term 2 from 2019)

The seminar includes a comprehensive introduction, methods and critical discussion of the proposed experimental design and research aims and hypotheses. There will also be time for questions form attendees. Marks based on scores from academics at the seminar. Summary of marks and comments will be provided as feedback by the Honours convenor following the seminar.

Two page reflection on three key seminars attended during Honours year. These can be SOVS Vaegan Seminars or other conference or University related to seminars attended during the Honours year. Assessed on communication clarity, style and critical assessment of seminar content and message. This is due in before the final Honours talk in Semester 2 (2018) or Term 3 (2019 and onwards)

These are assessed by the Honours supervisor, and marks provided to the student and Honours convenor.

contentlets.description:
Students in this course will undertake research under the supervision of an academic in the School of Optometry and Vision Science. Advanced training will be given in selected areas of vision science, including a supervised program that emphasises the use of specialised techniques relevant to the research area (for example laboratory-based, clinical or public heath techniques/applications), A written literature review and research proposal, ethics application and final research thesis are required. In addition, this course includes regular attendance at seminars. During the Honours year, students will be required to present two research seminars in the School of Optometry and Vision Science.

This course is only available to students undertaking Vision Science Honours within the School of Optometry and Vision Science, Faculty of Science. The course runs for the a whole year and requires enrolment each term, for 3 terms (16UOC each term). Applications are only accepted to commence in T1 or T3. All enrolment in VISN4016 should be with School's consent to ensure that students are only able to enrol if they have an appropriate project and supervisor.
contentlets.title: Vision Science Honours

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"VISN5511 - The Visual System, Impairments and Implications","description":"

This course provides students with a broad understanding of the visual system, its disorders, and how vision loss affects visually guided behaviour and daily activities. Its scope includes a review of the visual pathways, visual function and its measurement, as well as diseases and disorders of the visual system that lead to low vision and blindness.  The course also includes an introduction to educational strategies and training to improve orientation and mobility in people with vision loss. This course will be delivered online.

A multiple choice quiz will assess all course materials up to the mid-term exam (Week 5), including online practical work. Online practical work is designed to support consolidation of knowledge gained from online lectures. Mid-term exam mark will be provided within 2 weeks of assessment.

All course content will be assessed in the final exam. The format will be short answer, multiple choice, and problem-solving questions which will assess the student’s understanding and ability to clearly explain topics presented in the course. Feedback will be provided as the final course mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2a1ec5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d2a1ec5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"daa1ec5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"daa1ec5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52a1ec5cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961987","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a 2000 word research essay on an assigned topic. Topics will be released as the beginning of the term and will focus on key aspects on the course.

\n

The essay will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. Written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.

This precis will provide a summary of the initial research question and a concise review of research that will critically appraised in the essay.

\n

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"VISN5512 - Sensory Processes and Movement","description":"

This course provides students with an understanding of the brain, the sensory and motor systems and their integration in behavioural interactions with the environment. This course will cover topics such as the anatomy and organisation of the brain, the sensory systems such as vision, hearing and touch, motor processes such as body awareness, proprioception, and kinesthetics. This course will be delivered online and will be comprised of series of recorded lectures, tutorials and practicals. Key concepts will be reinforced through reading and online multimedia exercises. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"22a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961920","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

A final scheduled exam to assess the level of understanding of all course content. The format will be short answer, multiple choice and problem solving questions which will assess the student’s understanding and ability to clearly explain topics presented in the course. Feedback will be provided as the final course mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2aa1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"32a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"32a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3aa1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bea1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396192d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Written Assignment ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

This assignment will be in the form of a 2500 word critical review of current literature on an assigned topic on the impact of vision loss on sensory related processes and in particular movement behaviour. This assessment will therefore review and foster understanding of the sensory system, neural processes and how sensory information is used for behaviour, and how behaviour changes with deficits in sensory and motor processes. Students will be required to submit a precis of their literature review by Week 3, with feedback provided by the course convenor prior to the census date. The final review is due in Week 10 and feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2aa1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"32a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"32a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3aa1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f2a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Each student will be assigned a research topic at the beginning of term and they will be required to prepare a presentation and lead a group discussion on an assigned topic related to sensory processes and movement. Here topics might be research articles or an evaluation of past and current approaches to rehabilitation and orientation and mobility. Each student will give one presentation during the term with two different students scheduled to present their topics each week to the tutorial group.

\n

This assignment will be structured (30 minutes presentation, 20 minutes Q and A) and follow a rubric of required work which will be assessed by the coordinator.

This course provides students with foundational knowledge for the practice of orientation and mobility in Australian and international contexts. This course will be delivered online and includes a review of key disability philosophies, practice guidelines and inclusive practices for divisive clients of vision rehabilitation/habilitation services.

The format will be short answer, multiple choice, and problem-solving questions which will assess the student’s understanding and ability to clearly explain topics presented up to the middle of the course. Feedback will be provided as a mark two weeks after the test.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"87a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87a1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8fa1209cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9fa1609cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a 3000 word research essay on an assigned topic due at the end of term. Topics will be released as the beginning of the term and will focus on key aspects on the course. The essay will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. Written feedback on the final essay will be given in two weeks from submission.   

\n

Students will be required to submit a precis of their intended essay topic by Week 3, with feedback provided by the course convenor. This precis will provide a summary of the initial research question and a cursory review of research that will be in the essay.

It will also have evidence for clinical competency achievement. For this course, evidence of forming a personal practice philosophy will be reviewed. Feedback will be given at the end of term.

This course provides students with opportunities to learn, demonstrate and apply techniques, strategies and teaching while critically analysing them as tools for intervention design in orientation and mobility.  


The face to face practical component will involve supervised partner work, giving opportunity to embody simulation of travel for people who are blind or have low vision, while also refining the student’s instructional skills.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"73a1609cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396197f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Written Assignment - case reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a series of case reports on an assigned topic. These case reports provides examples of the types of clients, situations and techniques/skills that can be utilised by an orientation and mobility specialist. Topics will be released as the beginning of the term and will focus on key aspects on the course. The case reports will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. Written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.

contentlets.description:
This course provides students with opportunities to learn, demonstrate and apply techniques, strategies and teaching while critically analysing them as tools for intervention design in orientation and mobility.  

The face to face practical component will involve supervised partner work, giving opportunity to embody simulation of travel for people who are blind or have low vision, while also refining the student’s instructional skills.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"VISN5522 - Vision Rehabilitation ","description":"

This course provides students with a review of contemporary learning theories, vision enablers and the opportunity to apply critical analyses to emerging technology in the field of vision rehabilitation/habilitation. This course will cover a review of contemporary learning theories, vision enablers, a critical analysis of emerging technology. Further, this course will detail optical and non-optical aids, especially those that improve orientation and mobility in people with vision loss. Practicals will support learning with hand on use of low vision aids and their use for individuals with vision loss.

Topics will be released as the beginning of the term and will focus on key aspects on the course. The essay will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. Students will be required to submit a precis by Week 3, so that feedback may be provided prior to the census date. Written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.

This test will assess students practically on their knowledge and use of vision rehabilitation enablers (optical/non-optical) and technology and their application. Feedback will be provided as the final practical mark. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"10b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"10b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"98b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961932","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/VISN5522.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course provides students with a review of contemporary learning theories, vision enablers and the opportunity to apply critical analyses to emerging technology in the field of vision rehabilitation/habilitation. This course will cover a review of contemporary learning theories, vision enablers, a critical analysis of emerging technology. Further, this course will detail optical and non-optical aids, especially those that improve orientation and mobility in people with vision loss. Practicals will support learning with hand on use of low vision aids and their use for individuals with vision loss.
contentlets.title: Vision Rehabilitation

This course is designed to examine orientation and mobility intervention for additional client complexities.  Over two terms, this course will review the evidence base and techniques and strategies for appropriate modifications to intervention design according to complexity of the client scenario. It also provides the opportunity to develop and demonstrate clinical competencies through work integrated learning.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"64b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961971","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"e Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The online portfolio is a rolling document that will be marked on its structure, engagement, content and demonstration of reflective and critical analysis throughout the program. It will also have evidence for clinical competency achievement. For this course, a reflection piece will be reviewed. Feedback will be given at the end of term. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"64b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6cb1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6cb1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961972","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"20b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Written Assignment ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a case report series on different aspects of orientation and mobility practice. Students will be able to draw on their experience gained over the course, and have the opportunity to compile a collection of 4 cases. The case series will discuss different cases, critically review the clinical situation, and provide a plan for therapy. Written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"64b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6cb1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6cb1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961972","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24b1a09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Practical Competency","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"70","description":"

During work integrated learning, clinical competencies as outlined by OMAA and ACRVEP will be demonstrated by the student. Students will be assessed on whether they have competently met competencies. Feedback will be delivered during the placements with a summary of feedback at the end of each term.

This course provides provides students with a broad understanding of human development and ageing with respect to vision impairment and blindness. This course will be delivered online and its scope includes an in-depth review of child development, the effects of low vision and blindness on child development and the increased prevalence of vision impairment and co-morbidities with ageing.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"01b1e09cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396192d","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Written Assignment ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will require students to write a 3000 word essay supported with current evidence on an assigned topic. Topics will be released as the beginning of the term and will focus on key aspects on the course. The essay will be a review and critical analysis of a collection and synthesis of related research papers to answer the question. Written feedback will be given in two weeks from submission.

A test comprising of multiple choice, short answer and problem-solving questions will given to assess all course materials, including practical work. Practical work is designed to support consolidation of knowledge gained from online lectures. Feedback will be provided as the final course mark.

Students will be required to submit a precis of their intended essay topic by Week 3, with feedback provided by the course convenor. This precis will provide a summary of the initial research question and a cursory review of research that will be in the essay.
